member.summary: Gets or sets the request continuation token in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The request continuation token.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.SessionToken
member.summary: Gets or sets the session token for use with session consistency in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The session token for use with session consistency.
member.remarks: Useful for applications that are load balanced across multiple Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.DocumentClient instances. In this case, round-trip the token from end user to the application and then back to Azure Cosmos DB so that a session can be preserved across servers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.PartitionKeyRangeId
member.summary: Gets or sets the partition key range id for the current request in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: ChangeFeed requests can be executed against specific partition key ranges. This is used to process the change feed in parallel across multiple consumers. PartitionKeyRangeId cannot be specified along with PartitionKey.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.PartitionKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the partition key for the current request in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: PartitionKey cannot be specified along with PartitionKeyRangeId.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.StartFromBeginning
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether change feed in the Azure Cosmos DB service should start from beginning (true) or from current (false). By default it's start from current (false).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.StartTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time (exclusive) to start looking for changes after. If this is specified, StartFromBeginning is ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeedOptions.IncludeTentativeWrites
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether change feed in the Azure Cosmos DB service should return tentative writes in addition to committed writes. By default the flag is set to false meaning only committed writes will be sent in response.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Bootstrapping.PartitionSynchronizerCore.CreateLeasesAsync(System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.String})
member.summary: Creates leases if they do not exist. This might happen on initial start or if some lease was unexpectedly lost. Leases are created without the continuation token. It means partitions will be read according to 'From Beginning' or 'From current time'. Same applies also to split partitions. We do not search for parent lease and take continuation token since this might end up of reprocessing all the events since the split.

member.summary:
Gets or sets the delay in between polling the change feed for new changes, after all current changes are drained.
Applies only after a read on the change feed yielded no results.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.CheckpointFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets the frequency how often to checkpoint leases.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.MaxItemCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of items to be returned in the enumeration operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.StartContinuation
member.summary: Gets or sets the start request continuation token to start looking for changes after.
member.remarks: This is only used when lease store is not initialized and is ignored if a lease exists and has continuation token. If this is specified, both StartTime and StartFromBeginning are ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.StartTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time (exclusive) to start looking for changes after.
member.remarks: This is only used when: (1) Lease store is not initialized and is ignored if a lease exists and has continuation token. (2) StartContinuation is not specified. If this is specified, StartFromBeginning is ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.StartFromBeginning
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether change feed in the Azure Cosmos DB service should start from beginning (true) or from current (false). By default it's start from current (false).
member.remarks: This is only used when: (1) Lease store is not initialized and is ignored if a lease exists and has continuation token. (2) StartContinuation is not specified. (3) StartTime is not specified.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ChangeFeed.Configuration.ChangeFeedProcessorOptions.SessionToken

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ClearingSessionContainerClientRetryPolicy
member.summary:
This retry policy is designed to work with in a pair with ClientRetryPolicy. The inner retryPolicy must be a ClientRetryPolicy or a rety policy delegating to it.
The expectation that is the outer retry policy in the retry policy chain and nobody can overwrite ShouldRetryResult. Once we clear the session we expect call to fail and throw exceptio to the client. Otherwise we may violate session consistency.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionMode
member.summary: Represents the connection mode to be used by the client when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: Direct and Gateway connectivity modes are supported. Gateway is the default.

example.code: DocumentClient client = new DocumentClient(endpointUri, masterKey, new ConnectionPolicy { ConnectionMode = ConnectionMode.Direct });

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionMode.Gateway
member.summary: Use the Azure Cosmos DB gateway to route all requests to the Azure Cosmos DB service. The gateway proxies requests to the right data partition.
member.remarks: Use Gateway connectivity when within firewall settings do not allow Direct connectivity. All connections are made to the database account's endpoint through the standard HTTPS port (443).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionMode.Direct
member.summary: Uses direct connectivity to connect to the data nodes in the Azure Cosmos DB service. Use gateway only to initialize and cache logical addresses and refresh on updates
member.remarks: Use Direct connectivity for best performance. Connections are made to the data nodes on Azure Cosmos DB's clusters on a range of port numbers either using HTTPS or TCP/SSL.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy
member.summary: Represents the connection policy associated with a DocumentClient to connect to the Azure Cosmos DB service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class to connect to the Azure Cosmos DB service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.SetCurrentLocation(System.String)
member.summary: Automatically populates the for geo-replicated database accounts in the Azure Cosmos DB service, based on the current region that the client is running in.
member.param: The current region that this client is running in. E.g. "East US"

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MaxConcurrentFanoutRequests
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of concurrent fanout requests sent to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Default value is 32.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.RequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the request timeout in seconds when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service. The number specifies the time to wait for response to come back from network peer.
member.value: Default value is 60 seconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MediaRequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the media request timeout in seconds when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service. The number specifies the time to wait for response to come back from network peer for attachment content (a.k.a. media) operations.
member.value: Default value is 300 seconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.ConnectionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the connection mode used by the client when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Default value is
member.remarks: For more information, see Connection policy: Use direct connection mode.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MediaReadMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the attachment content (a.k.a. media) download mode when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Default value is .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.ConnectionProtocol
member.summary: Gets or sets the connection protocol when connecting to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Default value is .
member.remarks: This setting is not used when is set to . Gateway mode only supports HTTPS. For more information, see Connection policy: Use the TCP protocol.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.EnableReadRequestsFallback
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to allow for reads to go to multiple regions configured on an account of Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Default value is null.
member.remarks: If this property is not set, the default is true for all Consistency Levels other than Bounded Staleness, The default is false for Bounded Staleness. This property only has effect if the following conditions are satisifed: 1. is true 2. the Azure Cosmos DB account has more than one region

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.Default
member.summary: Gets the default connection policy used to connect to the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Refer to the default values for the individual properties of that determine the default connection policy.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.UserAgentSuffix
member.summary: A suffix to be added to the default user-agent for the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: Setting this property after sending any request won't have any effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.PreferredLocations
member.summary: Gets and sets the preferred locations (regions) for geo-replicated database accounts in the Azure Cosmos DB service. For example, "East US" as the preferred location.

remarks.para: When is true and the value of this property is non-empty, the SDK uses the locations in the collection in the order they are specified to perform operations, otherwise if the value of this property is not specified, the SDK uses the write region as the preferred location for all operations.
If is set to false, the value of this property is ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.EnableEndpointDiscovery
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag to enable endpoint discovery for geo-replicated database accounts in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is true, the SDK will automatically discover the current write and read regions to ensure requests are sent to the correct region based on the regions specified in the property. Default value is true indicating endpoint discovery is enabled.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.UseMultipleWriteLocations
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag to enable writes on any locations (regions) for geo-replicated database accounts in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: When the value of this property is true, the SDK will direct write operations to available writable locations of geo-replicated database account. Writable locations are ordered by property. Setting the property value to true has no effect until is also set to true. Default value is false indicating that writes are only directed to first region in property.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MaxConnectionLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of concurrent connections allowed for the target service endpoint in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.remarks: This setting is only applicable in Gateway mode.
member.value: Default value is 50.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.RetryOptions
member.summary: Gets or sets the associated with the in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: If this property is not set, the SDK uses the default retry policy that has set to 9 and set to 30 seconds.
member.remarks: For more information, see Handle rate limiting/request rate too large.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.IdleTcpConnectionTimeout
member.summary: (Direct/TCP) Controls the amount of idle time after which unused connections are closed.
member.value: By default, idle connections are kept open indefinitely. Value must be greater than or equal to 10 minutes. Recommended values are between 20 minutes and 24 hours.
member.remarks: Mainly useful for sparse infrequent access to a large database account.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.OpenTcpConnectionTimeout
member.summary: (Direct/TCP) Controls the amount of time allowed for trying to establish a connection.
member.value: The default timeout is 5 seconds. Recommended values are greater than or equal to 5 seconds.
member.remarks: When the time elapses, the attempt is cancelled and an error is returned. Longer timeouts will delay retries and failures.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MaxRequestsPerTcpConnection
member.summary: (Direct/TCP) Controls the number of requests allowed simultaneously over a single TCP connection. When more requests are in flight simultaneously, the direct/TCP client will open additional connections.
member.value: The default settings allow 30 simultaneous requests per connection. Do not set this value lower than 4 requests per connection or higher than 50-100 requests per connection. The former can lead to a large number of connections to be created. The latter can lead to head of line blocking, high latency and timeouts.
member.remarks: Applications with a very high degree of parallelism per connection, with large requests or responses, or with very tight latency requirements might get better performance with 8-16 requests per connection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MaxTcpConnectionsPerEndpoint
member.summary: (Direct/TCP) Controls the maximum number of TCP connections that may be opened to each Cosmos DB back-end. Together with MaxRequestsPerTcpConnection, this setting limits the number of requests that are simultaneously sent to a single Cosmos DB back-end(MaxRequestsPerTcpConnection x MaxTcpConnectionPerEndpoint).
member.value: The default value is 65,535. Value must be greater than or equal to 16.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.MaxTcpPartitionCount
member.summary: (Direct/TCP) This is an advanced setting that controls the number of TCP connections that will be opened eagerly to each Cosmos DB back-end.
member.value: Default value is 1. Applications with extreme performance requirements can set this value to 2.
member.remarks: This setting must be used with caution. When used improperly, it can lead to client machine ephemeral port exhaustion Azure SNAT port exhaustion.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy.PreferenceChanged
member.summary: GlobalEndpointManager will subscribe to this event if user updates the preferredLocations list in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClient
member.summary:
Provides a client-side logical representation of the Azure Cosmos DB account. This client can be used to configure and execute requests in the Azure Cosmos DB database service.
CosmosClient is thread-safe. Its recommended to maintain a single instance of CosmosClient per lifetime of the application which enables efficient connection management and performance. Please refer to performance guide at .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClient.CreateDatabaseAsync(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.RequestOptions,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Send a request for creating a database.
A database manages users, permissions and a set of containers. Each Azure Cosmos DB Database Account is able to support multiple independent named databases, with the database being the logical container for data.
Each Database consists of one or more containers, each of which in turn contain one or more documents. Since databases are an administrative resource, the Service Master Key will be required in order to access and successfully complete any action using the User APIs.
member.param: The database id.
(Optional) The throughput provisioned for a database in measurement of Request Units per second in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
(Optional) A set of options that can be set.
(Optional) representing request cancellation.
member.returns: A containing a which wraps a containing the resource record.
member.remarks: for details on provision throughput.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClient.CreateDatabaseIfNotExistsAsync(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.RequestOptions,System.Threading.CancellationToken)

summary.para: Check if a database exists, and if it doesn't, create it. Only the database id is used to verify if there is an existing database. Other database properties such as throughput are not validated and can be different then the passed properties.

A database manages users, permissions and a set of containers. Each Azure Cosmos DB Database Account is able to support multiple independent named databases, with the database being the logical container for data.

Each Database consists of one or more containers, each of which in turn contain one or more documents. Since databases are an administrative resource, the Service Master Key will be required in order to access and successfully complete any action using the User APIs.

member.param: The database id.
(Optional) The throughput provisioned for a database in measurement of Request Units per second in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
(Optional) A set of additional options that can be set.
(Optional) representing request cancellation.
member.returns: A containing a which wraps a containing the resource record.

listheader.description: Common success StatusCodes for the CreateDatabaseIfNotExistsAsync operation

item.description: Accepted - This means the database already exists.

member.remarks: for details on provision throughput.

member.remarks: The minimum interval is seconds. Any interval that is smaller will be ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.SerializerOptions
member.summary: Get to set optional serializer options.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.Serializer
member.summary: Get to set an optional JSON serializer. The client will use it to serialize or de-serialize user's cosmos request/responses. SDK owned types such as DatabaseProperties and ContainerProperties will always use the SDK default serializer.
member.remarks: To set a JSON.net serializer setting use . The constructor supports passing in the JsonSerializerSettings.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.PropertiesSerializer
member.summary: A JSON serializer used by the CosmosClient to serialize or de-serialize cosmos request/responses. The default serializer is always used for all system owned types like DatabaseProperties. The default serializer is used for user types if no UserJsonSerializer is specified

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.ConnectionProtocol
member.summary: Gets or sets the connection protocol when connecting to the Azure Cosmos service.
member.value: Default value is .
member.remarks: This setting is not used when is set to . Gateway mode only supports HTTPS. For more information, see Connection policy: Use the TCP protocol.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.SendingRequestEventArgs
member.summary: The event handler to be invoked before the request is sent.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.TransportClientHandlerFactory
member.summary: (Optional) transport interceptor factory

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.ApiType
member.summary: API type for the account

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.StoreClientFactory
member.summary: Optional store client factory instance to use for all transport requests.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.InitialRetryForRetryWithMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial delay retry time in milliseconds for the Azure Cosmos DB service for requests that hit RetryWithExceptions. This covers errors that occur due to concurrency errors in the store.
member.value: The default value is 1 second. For an example on how to set this value, please refer to .

remarks.para: When a request fails due to a RetryWith error, the client delays and retries the request. This configures the client to delay the time specified before retrying the request.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.MaximumRetryForRetryWithMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum delay retry time in milliseconds for the Azure Cosmos DB service for requests that hit RetryWithExceptions. This covers errors that occur due to concurrency errors in the store.
member.value: The default value is 30 seconds. For an example on how to set this value, please refer to .

remarks.para: When a request fails due to a RetryWith error, the client delays and retries the request. This configures the maximum time the client should delay before failing the request.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.RandomSaltForRetryWithMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval to salt retry with value. This will spread the retry values from 1..n from the exponential back-off subscribed.
member.value: The default value is to not salt.

remarks.para: When a request fails due to a RetryWith error, the client delays and retries the request. This configures the jitter on the retry attempted.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.TotalWaitTimeForRetryWithMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the total time to wait before failing the request for retry with failures. subscribed.
member.value: The default value 30 seconds.

remarks.para: When a request fails due to a RetryWith error, the client delays and retries the request. This configures total time spent waiting on the request.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.CosmosClientOptions.EnableCpuMonitor

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.DocumentClient.#ctor(System.Uri,System.Security.SecureString,Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy,System.Nullable{Microsoft.Azure.Documents.ConsistencyLevel})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified Azure Cosmos DB service endpoint, key, and connection policy for the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: The service endpoint to use to create the client.
The list of Permission objects to use to create the client.
(Optional) The connection policy for the client. If none is passed, the default is used
(Optional) This can be used to weaken the database account consistency level for read operations. If this is not set the database account consistency level will be used for all requests.
member.remarks:
The service endpoint and the authorization key can be obtained from the Azure Management Portal. The authKey used here is encrypted for privacy when being used, and deleted from computer memory when no longer needed
Using Direct connectivity, wherever possible, is recommended

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.DocumentClient.#ctor(System.Uri,System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.ConnectionPolicy,System.Nullable{Microsoft.Azure.Documents.ConsistencyLevel})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified service endpoint, an authorization key (or resource token) and a connection policy for the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: The service endpoint to use to create the client.
The authorization key or resource token to use to create the client.
(Optional) The connection policy for the client.
(Optional) The default consistency policy for client operations.
member.remarks:
The service endpoint can be obtained from the Azure Management Portal. If you are connecting using one of the Master Keys, these can be obtained along with the endpoint from the Azure Management Portal If however you are connecting as a specific Azure Cosmos DB User, the value passed to is the ResourceToken obtained from the permission feed for the user.
Using Direct connectivity, wherever possible, is recommended.

member.returns: A object.
member.remarks: This method is recommended to be called, after the constructor, but before calling any other methods on the DocumentClient instance. member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.DocumentClient.ResetSessionTokenRetryPolicy
member.summary: RetryPolicy retries a request when it encounters session unavailable (see ClientRetryPolicy). Once it exhausts all write regions it clears the session container, then it uses ClientCollectionCache to resolves the request's collection name. If it differs from the session container's resource id it explains the session unavailable exception: somebody removed and recreated the collection. In this case we retry once again (with empty session token) otherwise we return the error to the client (see RenameCollectionAwareClientRetryPolicy)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.DocumentClient.CreateDatabaseAsync(Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Database,Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.RequestOptions)
member.summary: Creates a database resource as an asychronous operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: The specification for the to create.
(Optional) The for the request.
member.returns: The that was created within a task object representing the service response for the asynchronous operation.
member.exception: If is not set.
Represents a consolidation of failures that occured during async processing. Look within InnerExceptions to find the actual exception(s).

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Database are:
StatusCodeReason for exception
400BadRequest - This means something was wrong with the database object supplied. It is likely that an id was not supplied for the new Database.
409Conflict - This means a with an id matching the id field of already existed.

member.summary: Creates a Document as an asychronous operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: The link of the to create the document in. E.g. dbs/db_rid/colls/coll_rid/
The document object to create.
(Optional) Any request options you wish to set. E.g. Specifying a Trigger to execute when creating the document.
(Optional) Disables the automatic id generation, If this is True the system will throw an exception if the id property is missing from the Document.
(Optional) A that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The that was created contained within a object representing the service response for the asynchronous operation.
member.exception: If either or is not set.
Represents a consolidation of failures that occured during async processing. Look within InnerExceptions to find the actual exception(s)

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception
400BadRequest - This means something was wrong with the document supplied. It is likely that was true and an id was not supplied
403Forbidden - This likely means the collection in to which you were trying to create the document is full.
409Conflict - This means a with an id matching the id field of already existed
413RequestEntityTooLarge - This means the exceeds the current max entity size. Consult documentation for limits and quotas.
429TooManyRequests - This means you have exceeded the number of request units per second. Consult the DocumentClientException.RetryAfter value to see how long you should wait before retrying this operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.DocumentClient.ReadDatabaseAsync(System.String,Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.RequestOptions)
member.summary: Reads a from the Azure Cosmos DB service as an asynchronous operation.
member.param: The link of the Database resource to be read.
(Optional) The request options for the request.
member.returns: A containing a which wraps a containing the read resource record.
member.exception: If is not set.

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception
404NotFound - This means the resource you tried to read did not exist.
429TooManyRequests - This means you have exceeded the number of request units per second. Consult the DocumentClientException.RetryAfter value to see how long you should wait before retrying this operation.

remarks.para: Doing a read of a resource is the most efficient way to get a resource from the Database. If you know the resource's ID, do a read instead of a query by ID.

The example shown uses ID-based links, where the link is composed of the ID properties used when the resources were created. You can still use the property of the Database if you prefer. A self-link is a URI for a resource that is made up of Resource Identifiers (or the _rid properties). ID-based links and SelfLink will both work. The format for is always "/dbs/{db identifier}" only the values within the {} change depending on which method you wish to use to address the resource.

The example shown user defined type ID-based links, where the link is composed of the ID properties used when the resources were created. You can still use the property of the UserDefinedType if you prefer. A self-link is a URI for a resource that is made up of Resource Identifiers (or the _rid properties). ID-based links and SelfLink will both work. The format for is always "/dbs/{db identifier}/udts/{user defined type identifier}" only the values within the {...} change depending on which method you wish to use to address the resource.

member.summary: Reads a as an asynchronous operation from the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: A URI to the Database resource to be read.
The request options for the request.
member.returns: A containing a which wraps a containing the read resource record.
member.exception: If is not set.

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception
404NotFound - This means the resource you tried to read did not exist.
429TooManyRequests - This means you have exceeded the number of request units per second. Consult the DocumentClientException.RetryAfter value to see how long you should wait before retrying this operation.

remarks.para: Doing a read of a resource is the most efficient way to get a resource from the service. If you know the resource's ID, do a read instead of a query by ID.

member.remarks: Used to manage query and ReadFeed execution. Can use FeedOptions to set page size (MaxItemCount)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class for the Azure Cosmos DB service.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.MaxItemCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of items to be returned in the enumeration operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The maximum number of items to be returned in the enumeration operation.
member.remarks: Used for query pagination. '-1' Used for dynamic page size.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.RequestContinuationToken
member.summary: Gets or sets the request continuation token in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The request continuation token.

example.code: // Resume query execution using the continuation from the previous query var queryable = client.CreateDocumentQuery<Book>(collectionLink, new FeedOptions { RequestContinuation = prevQuery.ResponseContinuation });

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.SessionToken
member.summary: Gets or sets the session token for use with session consistency in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The session token for use with session consistency.
member.remarks: Useful for applications that are load balanced across multiple Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.DocumentClient instances. In this case, round-trip the token from end user to the application and then back to Azure Cosmos DB so that a session can be preserved across servers.

example.code: var queryable = client.CreateDocumentQuery<Book>( collectionLink, new FeedOptions { SessionToken = lastSessionToken });

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.EnableScanInQuery
member.summary: Gets or sets the option to enable scans on the queries which couldn't be served as indexing was opted out on the requested paths in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Option is true if scan on queries is enabled; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.EnableCrossPartitionQuery
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether users are enabled to send more than one request to execute the query in the Azure Cosmos DB service. More than one request is necessary if the query is not scoped to single partition key value.
member.value: Option is true if cross-partition query execution is enabled; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: This option only applies to queries on documents and document attachments.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.EnableLowPrecisionOrderBy
member.summary: Gets or sets the option to enable low precision order by in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The option to enable low-precision order by.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.PartitionKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the for the current request in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

remarks.para: Partition key is required when read documents or attachments feed in a partitioned collection. Specifically Partition key is required for : . Only documents in partitions containing the is returned in the result.

member.example:
The following example shows how to read a document feed in a partitioned collection using . The example assumes the collection is created with a on the 'country' property in all the documents.
await client.ReadDocumentFeedAsync( collection.SelfLink, new RequestOptions { PartitionKey = new PartitionKey("USA") } );

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.PartitionKeyRangeId
member.summary: Gets or sets the partition key range id for the current request.

remarks.para: ReadFeed requests can use this to forward request to specific range. This is usefull in case of bulk export scenarios.

member.example:
The following example shows how to read a document feed in a partitioned collection from partition key range "20".
await client.ReadDocumentFeedAsync( collection.SelfLink, new RequestOptions { PartitionKeyRangeId = "20" } );

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.MaxDegreeOfParallelism
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of concurrent operations run client side during parallel query execution in the Azure Cosmos DB service. A positive property value limits the number of concurrent operations to the set value. If it is set to less than 0, the system automatically decides the number of concurrent operations to run.
member.value: The maximum number of concurrent operations during parallel execution. Defaults to 0.

example.code: var queryable = client.CreateDocumentQuery<Book>(collectionLink, new FeedOptions { MaxDegreeOfParallelism = 5});

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.MaxBufferedItemCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of items that can be buffered client side during parallel query execution in the Azure Cosmos DB service. A positive property value limits the number of buffered items to the set value. If it is set to less than 0, the system automatically decides the number of items to buffer.
member.value: The maximum count of items that can be buffered during parallel query execution.
member.remarks: This is only suggestive and cannot be abided by in certain cases.

example.code: var queryable = client.CreateDocumentQuery<Book>(collectionLink, new FeedOptions { MaximumBufferSize = 10, MaxDegreeOfParallelism = 2 });

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.EmitVerboseTracesInQuery
member.summary: Gets or sets the option to allow queries to emit out verbose traces for investigation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: Option is true if query tracing is enabled; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.FilterBySchemaResourceId
member.summary: Gets or sets the schema rid which could be used to filter the document feed response in order to focus on the documents for a particular schema.
member.value: By default, it is null which means no filtering will be applied. Otherwise, it must be a valid resource id of Schema resource.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.PopulateQueryMetrics
member.summary: Gets or sets the request option for document query requests in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

remarks.para: PopulateQueryMetrics is used to enable/disable getting metrics relating to query execution on document query requests.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.ResponseContinuationTokenLimitInKb
member.summary: Gets or sets the request option for document query requests in the Azure Cosmos DB service.

remarks.para: ResponseContinuationTokenLimitInKb is used to limit the length of continuation token in the query response. Valid values are >= 0.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.JsonSerializerSettings
member.summary: Gets or sets the for the current request used to deserialize the document. If null, uses the default serializer settings set up in the DocumentClient.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.ConsistencyLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the consistency level required for the feed (query/read feed) operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.value: The consistency level required for the request.
member.remarks:
Azure Cosmos DB offers 5 different consistency levels. Strong, Bounded Staleness, Session, Consistent Prefix and Eventual - in order of strongest to weakest consistency.
Azure Cosmos query/DB feed operations may be retrieved from many partitions, each accessed across many round trips. The consistency level is honored only within a partition and round trip.
While this is set at a database account level, Azure Cosmos DB allows a developer to override the default consistency level for each individual request.
member.example:
This example uses FeedOptions to override the consistency level to Eventual.
Document doc = client.ReadDocumentFeedAsync(documentLink, new FeedOptions { ConsistencyLevel = ConsistencyLevel.Eventual });

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.ForceQueryScan
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag that tells the backend to forces the query to perform a scan (at a request level).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.FeedOptions.EndEpk

The key to the account.

The example below creates a new with a ConsistencyLevel and a list of preferred locations.
CosmosClientBuilder cosmosClientBuilder = new CosmosClientBuilder( accountEndpoint: "https://testcosmos.documents.azure.com:443/", accountKey: "SuperSecretKey") .WithConsistencyLevel(ConsistencyLevel.Strong) .WithApplicationRegion("East US 2"); CosmosClient client = cosmosClientBuilder.Build();

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Fluent.CosmosClientBuilder.WithThrottlingRetryOptions(System.TimeSpan,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the minimum time to wait between retry and the max number of times to retry on throttled requests.
member.param: The maximum retry time in seconds for the Azure Cosmos DB service. Any interval that is smaller than a second will be ignored.
The number specifies the times retry requests for throttled requests.
member.para: When a request fails due to a rate limiting error, the service sends back a response that contains a value indicating the client should not retry before the time period has elapsed. This property allows the application to set a maximum wait time for all retry attempts. If the cumulative wait time exceeds the this value, the client will stop retrying and return the error to the application.
For more information, see Handle rate limiting/request rate too large.

member.summary: Handler which manages the continuation token and partition-key-range-id selection depending on a provided start and end epk and direction. By default start is 00, end is FF and direction is forward. It doesn't participates in split logic directly but on split retry, will select the new appropriate partition-key-range id after a forced refresh of the CollectionRoutingMap.

StatusCodeReason for exception
400BadRequest - This means something was wrong with the database object supplied. It is likely that an id was not supplied for the new Database.
409Conflict - This means a with an id matching the id field of already existed.

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception

429TooManyRequests - This means you have exceeded the number of request units per second. Consult the DocumentClientException.RetryAfter value to see how long you should wait before retrying this operation.

remarks.para: Doing a read of a resource is the most efficient way to get a resource from the Database. If you know the resource's ID, do a read instead of a query by ID.

The example shown uses ID-based links, where the link is composed of the ID properties used when the resources were created. You can still use the property of the Database if you prefer. A self-link is a URI for a resource that is made up of Resource Identifiers (or the _rid properties). ID-based links and SelfLink will both work. The format for is always "/dbs/{db identifier}" only the values within the {} change depending on which method you wish to use to address the resource.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.IDocumentClient.UpsertDocumentAsync(System.String,System.Object,Microsoft.Azure.Documents.Client.RequestOptions,System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Upserts a Document as an asychronous operation in the Azure Cosmos DB service.
member.param: The link of the to upsert the document in. E.g. dbs/db_rid/colls/coll_rid/
The document object to upsert.
(Optional) Any request options you wish to set. E.g. Specifying a Trigger to execute when creating the document.
(Optional) Disables the automatic id generation, If this is True the system will throw an exception if the id property is missing from the Document.
(Optional) A that can be used by other objects or threads to receive notice of cancellation.
member.returns: The that was upserted contained within a object representing the service response for the asynchronous operation.
member.exception: If either or is not set.
Represents a consolidation of failures that occured during async processing. Look within InnerExceptions to find the actual exception(s)

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception
400BadRequest - This means something was wrong with the document supplied. It is likely that was true and an id was not supplied
403Forbidden - This likely means the collection in to which you were trying to upsert the document is full.
409Conflict - This means a with an id matching the id field of already existed
413RequestEntityTooLarge - This means the exceeds the current max entity size. Consult documentation for limits and quotas.
429TooManyRequests - This means you have exceeded the number of request units per second. Consult the DocumentClientException.RetryAfter value to see how long you should wait before retrying this operation.

This exception can encapsulate many different types of errors. To determine the specific error always look at the StatusCode property. Some common codes you may get when creating a Document are:
StatusCodeReason for exception

413RequestEntityTooLarge - This means the body of the you tried to upsert was too large.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Common.AsyncCache`2
member.summary: Cache which supports asynchronous value initialization. It ensures that for given key only single inintialization funtion is running at any point in time.
member.typeparam: Type of keys.
Type of values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Common.AsyncCache`2.GetAsync(`0,`1,System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task{`1}},System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Boolean)

summary.para: Gets value corresponding to .
If another initialization function is already running, new initialization function will not be started. The result will be result of currently running initialization function.
If previous initialization function is successfully completed - value returned by it will be returned unless it is equal to , in which case new initialization function will be started.
If previous initialization function failed - new one will be launched.

member.param: Key for which to get a value.
Value which is obsolete and needs to be refreshed.
Initialization function.
Cancellation token.
Skip cached value and generate new value.
member.returns: Cached value or value returned by initialization function.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Common.AsyncCache`2.RemoveAsync(`0)
member.summary: Remove value from cache and return it if present.
member.returns: Value if present, default value if not present.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Common.AsyncCache`2.BackgroundRefreshNonBlocking(`0,System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task{`1}})
member.summary: Runs a background task that will started refreshing the cached value for a given key. This observes the same logic as GetAsync - a running value will still take precedence over a call to this.
member.param: Key.
Generator function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonBinaryEncoding.ValueLengths.lengths
member.summary: Lookup table for encoded value length for each TypeMarker value (0 to 255) The lengths are encoded as follows: - Positive Value: The length of the value including its TypeMarker - Negative Value: The length is encoded as an integer of size equals to abs(value) following the TypeMarker byte - Zero Value: The length is unknown (for instance an unassigned type marker)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonBinaryEncoding.StringLengths.lengths
member.summary: Lookup table for encoded string length for each TypeMarker value (0 to 255) The lengths are encoded as follows: - Non-Negative Value: The TypeMarker encodes the string length - Negative Value: System or user dictionary encoded string, or encoded string length that follows the TypeMarker

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNavigator.JsonTextNavigator.JsonTextParser
member.summary: The JsonTextParser class is used to get a JSON AST / DOM from plaintext using a JsonTextReader as a lexer / tokenizer. Internally the parser is implemented as an LL(1) parser, since JSON is unambiguous and we can just parse it using recursive decent.

member.returns: The root node of a JSON AST from a jsonTextReader.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType
member.summary: The enumeration of JSON node types

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Null
member.summary: Corresponds to the 'null' value in JSON.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.False
member.summary: Corresponds to the 'false' value in JSON.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.True
member.summary: Corresponds to the 'true' value in JSON.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Number
member.summary: Corresponds to the number type in JSON (number = [ minus ] integer [ fraction ] [ exponent ])

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.String
member.summary: Corresponds to the string type in JSON (string = quotation-mark *char quotation-mark)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Array
member.summary: Corresponds to the array type in JSON ( begin-array [ value *( value-separator value ) ] end-array)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Object
member.summary: Corresponds to the object type in JSON (begin-object [ member *( value-separator member ) ] end-object)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.FieldName
member.summary: Corresponds to the property name of a JSON object property (which is also a string).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Int8
member.summary: Corresponds to the sbyte type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Int16
member.summary: Corresponds to the short type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Int32
member.summary: Corresponds to the int type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Int64
member.summary: Corresponds to the long type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.UInt32
member.summary: Corresponds to the uint type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Float32
member.summary: Corresponds to the float type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Float64
member.summary: Corresponds to the double type in C# for the extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Binary
member.summary: Corresponds to an arbitrary sequence of bytes (equivalent to a byte[] in C#)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Guid
member.summary: Corresponds to a GUID type in C# for teh extended types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonNodeType.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown JsonNodeType.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState
member.summary: This class maintains the current state of a JSON object/value while it is being read or written.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.JsonMaxNestingDepth
member.summary: This constant defines the maximum nesting depth that the parser supports. The JSON spec states that this is an implementation dependent thing, so we're just picking a value for now. FWIW .Net chose 100 Note: This value needs to be a multiple of 8 and must be less than 2^15 (see asserts in the constructor)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.readMode
member.summary: Flag for determining whether to throw exceptions that connote a context at the end or not started / complete.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.nestingStackBitmap
member.summary: Stores a bitmap for whether we are in an array or object context at a particular level (0 => array, 1 => object).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.nestingStackIndex
member.summary: The current nesting stack index.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.currentTokenType
member.summary: The current JsonTokenType.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.currentContext
member.summary: The current JsonObjectContext.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the JsonObjectState class.
member.param: Flag for determining whether to throw exceptions that correspond to a JsonReader or JsonWriter.

member.summary: Context at the start of the object state.

member.summary: Context when state is in an array.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.JsonObjectContext.Object
member.summary: Context when state is in an object.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current context is an array.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.InObjectContext
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current context in an object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.RetrieveCurrentContext
member.summary: Gets the current JsonObjectContext

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonObjectState.Mask
member.summary: Gets a mask to use to get the current context from the nesting stack

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonReader
member.summary: Base abstract class for JSON readers. The reader defines methods that allow for reading a JSON encoded value as a stream of tokens. The tokens are traversed in the same order as they appear in the JSON document.
Partial JsonReader with a private JsonBinaryReader implementation

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonReader.JsonBinaryReader.progressStack
member.summary: For binary there is no end of token marker in the actual binary, but the JsonReader interface still needs to surface ObjectEndToken and ArrayEndToken. To accommodate for this we have a progress stack to let us know how many bytes there are left to read for all levels of nesting. With this information we know that we are at the end of a context and can now surface an end object / array token.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonReader.JsonBinaryReader.ProcessJsonToken(Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonTokenType,Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonReader.JsonBinaryReader.ProcessJsonTokenCallback)
member.summary: Given a jsonTokenType and supplied callback this function will update jsonBuffer, jsonObject, and progressStack. The buffer will know the current token type, where that token starts and ends. The object state will also know the current token type. Finally the progress stack will add a new context if there is one and make progress on all parent context.
member.param: The type of token being processed.
The callback used to actually process the token.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonBinaryWriter
member.summary: Concrete implementation of that knows how to serialize to binary encoding.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonBinaryWriter.binaryWriter
member.summary: Writer used to write fully materialized context to the internal stream.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonBinaryWriter.bufferedContexts
member.summary: With binary encoding all the json elements are length prefixed, unfortunately the caller of this class only provides what tokens to write. This means that whenever a user call WriteObject/ArrayStart we don't know the length of said object or array until WriteObject/ArrayEnd is invoked. To get around this we reserve some space for the length and write to it when the user supplies the end token. This stack remembers for each nesting level where it begins and how many items it has.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonBinaryWriter.serializeCount
member.summary: With binary encoding json elements like arrays and object are prefixed with a length in bytes and optionally a count. This flag just determines whether you want to serialize the count, since it's optional and up to the user to make the tradeoff between O(1) .Count() operation as the cost of additional storage.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonBinaryWriter.reservationSize
member.summary: When a user writes an open array or object we reserve this much space for the type marker + length + count And correct it later when they write a close array or object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Json.JsonWriter.JsonTextWriter
member.summary: This class is used to build a JSON string. It supports our defined IJsonWriter interface. It keeps an stack to keep track of scope, and provides error checking using that. It has few other variables for error checking The user can also provide initial size to reserve string buffer, that will help reduce cost of reallocation. It provides error checking based on JSON grammar. It provides escaping for nine characters specified in JSON.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.DocumentQueryable
member.summary: This class provides extension methods for converting a object to a object.
member.remarks: The class provides implementation of standard query methods for querying resources in Azure Cosmos DB. These methods enable you to express traversal, filter, and projection operations over data persisted in the Azure Cosmos DB service. They are defined as methods that extend IQueryable, and do not perform any querying directly. Instead, their functionality is to create queries based the resource and query expression provided. The actual query execution occurs when enumeration forces the expression tree associated with an IQueryable object to be executed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.ExpressionToSql.ConvertToScalarAnyCollection(Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.TranslationContext)
member.summary: Convert the context's current query to a scalar Any collection by wrapping it as following: SELECT VALUE COUNT(v0) > 0 FROM (current query) AS v0. This is used in cases where LINQ expression ends with Any() which is a boolean scalar. Normally Any would translate to SELECT VALUE EXISTS() subquery. However that wouldn't work for these cases because it would result in a boolean value for each row instead of one single "aggregated" boolean value.
member.param: The translation context
member.returns: The scalar Any collection

member.summary: Visit an lambda expression which is in side a lambda and translate it to a scalar expression or a subquery scalar expression. See the other overload of this method for more details.

The translation context
member.returns: A scalar expression representing the input expression

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.ExpressionToSql.VisitScalarExpression(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression,Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.TranslationContext)
member.summary: Visit an lambda expression which is in side a lambda and translate it to a scalar expression or a collection scalar expression. If it is a collection scalar expression, e.g. should be translated to subquery such as SELECT VALUE ARRAY, SELECT VALUE EXISTS, SELECT VALUE [aggregate], the subquery will be aliased to a new binding for the FROM clause. E.g. consider Select(family => family.Children.Select(child => child.Grade)). Since the inner Select corresponds to a subquery, this method would create a new binding of v0 to the subquery SELECT VALUE ARRAY(), and the inner expression will be just SELECT v0.
member.param: The input expression
The translation context
member.returns: A scalar expression representing the input expression

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.QueryUnderConstruction.GetSubquery(Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Linq.QueryUnderConstruction)
member.summary: Separate out the query branch, which makes up a subquery and is built on top of the parent query chain. E.g. Let the query chain at some point in time be q0 - q1 - q2. When a subquery is recognized, its expression is visited. Assume that adds 2 queries to the chain to q0 - q1 - q2 - q3 - q4. Invoking q4.GetSubquery(q2) would return q3 - q4 after it's isolated from the rest of the chain.
member.param: The last query in the chain before the collection expression is visited
member.returns: The subquery that has been decoupled from the parent query chain

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.Aggregation.AverageAggregator
member.summary: Concrete implementation of IAggregator that can take the global weighted average from the local weighted average of multiple partitions and continuations. The way this works is that for each continuation in each partition we decompose the average into a sum and count. Let us denote the sum and count for the ith continuation in the jth partition as (sum_i,j, count_i,j), then the true average for the whole query is SUM(sum_i,j for all i and all j) / SUM(count_i,j for all i and all j), this way the average is weighted across continuation and partitions that have more or less documents contributing to their average.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext
member.summary: This class is responsible for maintaining a forest of . The trees in this forest are ordered using a priority queue and the nodes within the forest are internally ordered using a comparator. The ordering is determine by the concrete derived class. This class allows derived classes to iterate through the documents in the forest using Current and MoveNext semantics. This class is also responsible for prefetching documents if necessary using whose ordering is also determined by the derived classes. This class also aggregated all metrics from sending queries to individual partitions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.DynamicPageSizeAdjustmentFactor
member.summary: When a document producer tree successfully fetches a page we increase the page size by this factor so that any particular document producer will only ever make O(log(n)) roundtrips, while also only ever grabbing at most twice the number of documents needed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.actualMaxBufferedItemCount

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.groupedQueryMetrics
member.summary: This stores all the query metrics which have been grouped by partition id. When a feed response is returned (which includes multiple partitions and potentially multiple continuations) we take a snapshot of partitionedQueryMetrics and store it in grouped query metrics.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.partitionedQueryMetrics
member.summary: This stores the running query metrics. When a feed response is returned he take a snapshot of this bag and store it in groupedQueryMetrics. The bag is then emptied and available to store the query metric for future continuations.
member.remarks: Due to the nature of parallel queries and prefetches the query metrics you get for a single continuation does not always map to how much work was done to get that continuation. For example say for a simple cross partition query we return the first page of the results from the first partition, but behind the scenes we prefetched from other partitions. Another example is for an order by query we return one page of results but it only required us to use partial pages from each partition, but we eventually used the whole page for the next continuation; which continuation reports the cost? Basically the only thing we can ensure is if you drain a query fully you should get back the same query metrics by the end.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.totalBufferedItems
member.summary: Total number of buffered items to determine if we can go for another prefetch while still honoring the MaxBufferedItemCount.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosCrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.GetActiveItemProducers
member.summary: After a split you need to maintain the continuation tokens for all the child document producers until a condition is met. For example lets say that a document producer is at continuation X and it gets split, then the children each get continuation X, but since you only drain from one of them at a time you are left with the first child having continuation X + delta and the second child having continuation X (draw this out if you are following along). At this point you have the answer the question: "Which continuation token do you return to the user?". Let's say you return X, then when you come back to the first child you will be repeating work, thus returning some documents more than once. Let's say you return X + delta, then you fine when you return to the first child, but when you get to the second child you don't have a continuation token meaning that you will be repeating all the document for the second partition up until X and again you will be returning some documents more than once. Thus you have to return the continuation token for both children. Both this means you are returning more than 1 continuation token for the rest of the query. Well a naive optimization is to flush the continuation for a child partition once you are done draining from it, which isn't bad for a parallel query, but if you have an order by query you might not be done with a producer until the end of the query. The next optimization for a parallel query is to flush the continuation token the moment you start reading from a child partition. This works for a parallel query, but breaks for an order by query. The final realization is that for an order by query you are only choosing between multiple child partitions when their is a tie, so the key is that you can dump the continuation token the moment you come across a new order by item. For order by queries that is determined by the order by field and for parallel queries that is the moment you come by a new rid (which is any document, since rids are unique within a partition). So by passing an equality comparer to the document producers they can determine whether they are still "active".
member.returns: Returns all document producers whose continuation token you have to return. Only during a split will this list contain more than 1 item.

summary.para: If a query encounters split up resuming using continuation, we need to regenerate the continuation tokens. Specifically, since after split we will have new set of ranges, we need to remove continuation token for the parent partition and introduce continuation token for the child partitions.

This function does that. Also in that process, we also check validity of the input continuation tokens. For example, even after split the boundary ranges of the child partitions should match with the parent partitions. If the Min and Max range of a target partition in the continuation token was Min1 and Max1. Then the Min and Max range info for the two corresponding child partitions C1Min, C1Max, C2Min, and C2Max should follow the constrain below: PMax = C2Max > C2Min > C1Max > C1Min = PMin.

member.param: The partition key ranges to extract continuation tokens for.
The continuation token that the user supplied.
The output dictionary of partition key range to continuation token.
member.typeparam: The type of continuation token to generate.
member.Remarks: The code assumes that merge doesn't happen and
member.returns: The index of the partition whose MinInclusive is equal to the suppliedContinuationTokens

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext
member.summary: CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext is a concrete implementation for CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext. This class is responsible for draining cross partition queries that have order by conditions. The way order by queries work is that they are doing a k-way merge of sorted lists from each partition with an added condition. The added condition is that if 2 or more top documents from different partitions are equivalent then we drain from the left most partition first. This way we can generate a single continuation token for all n partitions. This class is able to stop and resume execution by generating continuation tokens and reconstructing an execution context from said token.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext.FormatPlaceHolder
member.summary: Order by queries are rewritten to allow us to inject a filter. This placeholder is so that we can just string replace it with the filter we want without having to understand the structure of the query.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext.True
member.summary: If query does not need a filter then we replace the FormatPlaceHolder with "true", since "SELECT * FROM c WHERE blah and true" is the same as "SELECT * FROM c where blah"

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext.FetchPriorityFunction
member.summary: Function to determine the priority of fetches. Basically we are fetching from the partition with the least number of buffered documents first.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext.skipCount
member.summary: Skip count used for JOIN queries. You can read up more about this in the documentation for the continuation token.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext.previousRid
member.summary: We need to keep track of the previousRid, since order by queries don't drain full pages.

members.member:
Initializes a new instance of the CosmosOrderByItemQueryExecutionContext class.
The params used to construct the base class. For cross partition order by queries a query like "SELECT c.id, c.field_0 ORDER BY r.field_7 gets rewritten as:
SELECT r._rid, [{"item": r.field_7}] AS orderByItems, {"id": r.id, "field_0": r.field_0} AS payload FROM r WHERE({ document db - formattable order by query - filter}) ORDER BY r.field_7 This is needed because we need to add additional filters to the query when we resume from a continuation, and it lets us easily parse out the _rid orderByItems, and payload without parsing the entire document (and having to remember the order by field). Comparer used to internally compare documents from different sorted partitions.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosParallelItemQueryExecutionContext
member.summary: CosmosParallelItemQueryExecutionContext is a concrete implementation for CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext. This class is responsible for draining cross partition queries that do not have order by conditions. The way parallel queries work is that it drains from the left most partition first. This class handles draining in the correct order and can also stop and resume the query by generating a continuation token and resuming from said continuation token.

member.param: The parameters for constructing the base class.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CosmosParallelItemQueryExecutionContext.ContinuationToken
member.summary: For parallel queries the continuation token semantically holds two pieces of information: 1) What physical partition did the user read up to 2) How far into said partition did they read up to And since the client consumes queries strictly in a left to right order we can partition the documents: 1) Documents left of the continuation token have been drained 2) Documents to the right of the continuation token still need to be served. This is useful since we can have a single continuation token for all partitions.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext
member.summary: This class is responsible for maintaining a forest of . The trees in this forest are ordered using a priority queue and the nodes within the forest are internally ordered using a comparator. The ordering is determine by the concrete derived class. This class allows derived classes to iterate through the documents in the forest using Current and MoveNext semantics. This class is also responsible for prefetching documents if necessary using whose ordering is also determined by the derived classes. This class also aggregated all metrics from sending queries to individual partitions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.DynamicPageSizeAdjustmentFactor
member.summary: When a document producer tree successfully fetches a page we increase the page size by this factor so that any particular document producer will only ever make O(log(n)) roundtrips, while also only ever grabbing at most twice the number of documents needed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.documentProducerForest
member.summary: Priority Queue of DocumentProducerTrees that make a forest that can be iterated on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.fetchPrioirtyFunction
member.summary: Function used to determine which document producer to fetch from first

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.comparableTaskScheduler
member.summary: The task scheduler that kicks off all the prefetches behind the scenes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.equalityComparer
member.summary: The equality comparer used to determine whether a document producer needs it's continuation token to be part of the composite continuation token.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.requestChargeTracker
member.summary: Request Charge Tracker used to atomically add request charges (doubles).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.actualMaxPageSize
member.summary: The actual max page size after all the optimizations have been made it in the create document query execution context layer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.actualMaxBufferedItemCount
member.summary: The actual max buffered item count after all the optimizations have been made it in the create document query execution context layer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.groupedQueryMetrics
member.summary: This stores all the query metrics which have been grouped by partition id. When a feed response is returned (which includes multiple partitions and potentially multiple continuations) we take a snapshot of partitionedQueryMetrics and store it in grouped query metrics.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.partitionedQueryMetrics
member.summary: This stores the running query metrics. When a feed response is returned he take a snapshot of this bag and store it in groupedQueryMetrics. The bag is then emptied and available to store the query metric for future continuations.
member.remarks: Due to the nature of parallel queries and prefetches the query metrics you get for a single continuation does not always map to how much work was done to get that continuation. For example say for a simple cross partition query we return the first page of the results from the first partition, but behind the scenes we prefetched from other partitions. Another example is for an order by query we return one page of results but it only required us to use partial pages from each partition, but we eventually used the whole page for the next continuation; which continuation reports the cost? Basically the only thing we can ensure is if you drain a query fully you should get back the same query metrics by the end.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.totalBufferedItems
member.summary: Total number of buffered items to determine if we can go for another prefetch while still honoring the MaxBufferedItemCount.

member.summary: The total response length.

member.param: Constructor parameters for the base class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos.Query.CrossPartitionQueryExecutionContext.GetActiveDocumentProducers
member.summary: After a split you need to maintain the continuation tokens for all the child document producers until a condition is met. For example lets say that a document producer is at continuation X and it gets split, then the children each get continuation X, but since you only drain from one of them at a time you are left with the first child having continuation X + delta and the second child having continuation X (draw this out if you are following along). At this point you have the answer the question: "Which continuation token do you return to the user?". Let's say you return X, then when you come back to the first child you will be repeating work, thus returning some documents more than once. Let's say you return X + delta, then you fine when you return to the first child, but when you get to the second child you don't have a continuation token meaning that you will be repeating all the document for the second partition up until X and again you will be returning some documents more than once. Thus you have to return the continuation token for both children. Both this means you are returning more than 1 continuation token for the rest of the query. Well a naive optimization is to flush the continuation for a child partition once you are done draining from it, which isn't bad for a parallel query, but if you have an order by query you might not be done with a producer until the end of the query. The next optimization for a parallel query is to flush the continuation token the moment you start reading from a child partition. This works for a parallel query, but breaks for an order by query. The final realization is that for an order by query you are only choosing between multiple child partitions when their is a tie, so the key is that you can dump the continuation token the moment you come across a new order by item. For order by queries that is determined by the order by field and for parallel queries that is the moment you come by a new rid (which is any document, since rids are unique within a partition). So by passing an equality comparer to the document producers they can determine whether they are still "active".
member.returns: Returns all document producers whose continuation token you have to return. Only during a split will this list contain more than 1 item.

summary.para: If a query encounters split up resuming using continuation, we need to regenerate the continuation tokens. Specifically, since after split we will have new set of ranges, we need to remove continuation token for the parent partition and introduce continuation token for the child partitions.

This function does that. Also in that process, we also check validity of the input continuation tokens. For example, even after split the boundary ranges of the child partitions should match with the parent partitions. If the Min and Max range of a target partition in the continuation token was Min1 and Max1. Then the Min and Max range info for the two corresponding child partitions C1Min, C1Max, C2Min, and C2Max should follow the constrain below: PMax = C2Max > C2Min > C1Max > C1Min = PMin.

member.param: The partition key ranges to extract continuation tokens for.
The continuation token that the user supplied.
The output dictionary of partition key range to continuation token.
member.typeparam: The type of continuation token to generate.
member.Remarks: The code assumes that merge doesn't happen and
member.returns: The index of the partition whose MinInclusive is equal to the suppliedContinuationTokens
